bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to John B. Moore, September 16, 1898
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: INDEX BUREAU REC'D 28 OCT '98 DEPT OF STATE
No. 3, Consular Series, Consulate General, Monrovia Liberia Sept 16, 1898
Owen L. W. Smith, to Hon. John B. Moore, Asstistant Secretary of State, Wasington.
No. 3, Consular Series Consulate General, Monrovia, Liberia; Sept. 16, 1898.
Hon. John B. Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, Wasington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit to you the intelligence that on the 6th of Sept., 1898, I vacated the quarters rented by my predecessor, Hon. W. H. Heard, for the use of the Legation; and moved back to the building, formerly rented of Mr. Sharp, and used as the Legation, prior to the administration of the Hon. Mr. Heard, on the 7th instant. The present quarters, not having been retired to any specially selected

class of persons, since to vacation by the Hon. Mr. Heard, was found to have been very badly used; the repairs of which are now going on, at the expense of the premises; while the Legation pays for cleaning building and premises.
The terms of the contract have not yet been reduced to writing but do soon as possible, will furnish the Department with a copy.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith
